Models#

MPS#

class tensorkrowch.MPS(n_sites, d_phys, d_bond, boundary='obc', param_bond=False, num_batches=1, inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Create an MPS module.

Parameters

  • n_sites (number of sites, including the input and output_node sites) –

  • d_phys (physic dimension) –

  • d_bond (bond dimension. If given as a sequence, the i-th bond) – dimension is always the dimension of the right edge of th i-th node

  • boundary (string indicating whether we are using periodic or open) – boundary conditions

  • param_bond (boolean indicating whether bond edges should be parametric) –

  • num_batches (number of batch edges of input data) –

  • inline_input (boolean indicating whether input should be contracted) – inline or in a single stacked contraction

  • inline_mats (boolean indicating whether sequence of matrices) – should be contracted inline or as a sequence of pairwise stacked contrations

param_bond(set_param=None)[source]#

Return param_bond attribute or change it if set_param is provided.

Parameters

set_param (boolean indicating whether edges have to be parameterized) – (True) or de-parameterized (False)

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes with as many batch edges as num_batch_edges and one feature edge, and connects each of these feature edges to an edge from the list input_edges (following the provided order).

If all the data nodes have the same shape, a virtual node will contain all the tensors stacked in one, what will save some memory and time in computations.

This method can be overriden in subclasses so that it is specified in its implementation to which edges of the network the data nodes should be connected. In this case, there is no need to call set_data_nodes explicitly during training, since it will be done in the forward() call. Otherwise, it should be called before starting training.

Parameters

  • input_edges (list[int] or list[Edge or ParamEdge]) – List of edges (or indices of edges() if given as int) to which the data nodes’ feature edges will be connected.

  • num_batch_edges (int) – Number of batch edges in the data nodes.

contract(inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Contracts the whole tensor network returning a single Node. This method is not implemented and should be overriden in subclasses of TensorNetwork.

canonicalize(oc=None, mode='svd', rank=None, cum_percentage=None, cutoff=None)[source]#

Turns the MPS into canonical form

Parameters

  • oc (orthogonality center position) –

  • mode (can be either 'svd', 'svdr' or 'qr') –

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes with as many batch edges as num_batch_edges and one feature edge, and connects each of these feature edges to an edge from the list input_edges (following the provided order).

If all the data nodes have the same shape, a virtual node will contain all the tensors stacked in one, what will save some memory and time in computations.

This method can be overriden in subclasses so that it is specified in its implementation to which edges of the network the data nodes should be connected. In this case, there is no need to call set_data_nodes explicitly during training, since it will be done in the forward() call. Otherwise, it should be called before starting training.

Parameters

  • num_batch_edges (int) – Number of batch edges in the data nodes.

contract(inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Contracts the whole tensor network returning a single Node. This method is not implemented and should be overriden in subclasses of TensorNetwork.

MPSLayer#

class tensorkrowch.MPSLayer(n_sites, d_phys, n_labels, d_bond, l_position=None, boundary='obc', param_bond=False, num_batches=1, inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Class for Matrix Product States with an extra node that is dedicated to the output. That is, this MPS has \(n\) nodes, being \(n-1\) input nodes connected to data nodes (nodes that will contain the data tensors), and one output node, whose physical dimension is used as the label (for classification tasks).

Besides, since this class has an output edge, when contracting the whole tensor network (with input data), the result will be a vector that can be plugged into the next layer (being this other tensor network or a neural network layer).

If the physical dimensions of all the input nodes are equal, the input data tensor can be passed as a single tensor. Otherwise, it would have to be passed as a list of tensors with different sizes.

Parameters

  • n_sites (int) – Number of sites, including all the input nodes and the output node.

  • d_phys (int, list[int] or tuple[int]) – Physical dimension(s). If given as a sequence, its length should be equal to n_sites - 1, since these are the physical dimensions of the input nodes.

  • n_labels (int) – Label dimension for the output node. Plays the same role as d_phys for input nodes.

  • d_bond (int, list[int] or tuple[int]) – Bond dimension(s). If given as a sequence, its length should be equal to n_sites. The i-th bond dimension is always the dimension of the right edge of the i-th node (including output node).

  • l_position (int, optional) – Position of the output node (label). Should be between 0 and n_sites - 1. If None, the output node will be located at the middle of the MPS.

  • boundary ({'obc', 'pbc'}) – String indicating whether periodic or open boundary conditions should be used.

  • param_bond (bool) – Boolean indicating whether bond edges should be ParamEdge.

  • num_batches (int) – Number of batch edges of input data nodes. Usually num_batches = 1 (where the batch edge is used for the data batched) but it could also be num_batches = 2 (one edge for data batched, other edge for image patches in convolutional layers).

  • inline_input (bool) – Boolean indicating whether input data nodes should be contracted inline (one contraction at a time) or in a single stacked contraction.

  • inline_mats (bool) – Boolean indicating whether the sequence of matrices (resultant after contracting the input data nodes) should be contracted inline or as a sequence of pairwise stacked contrations.

Examples

MPSLayer with same physical dimensions:

>>> mps_layer = tk.MPSLayer(n_sites=5,
...                         d_phys=2,
...                         n_labels=10,
...                         d_bond=5)
>>> data = torch.ones(4, 20, 2) # n_features x batch_size x feature_size
>>> result = mps_layer(data)
>>> print(result.shape)
torch.Size([20, 10])

MPSLayer with different physical dimensions:

>>> mps_layer = tk.MPSLayer(n_sites=5,
...                         d_phys=list(range(2, 6)),
...                         n_labels=10,
...                         d_bond=5)
>>> data = [torch.ones(20, i)
...         for i in range(2, 6)] # n_features * [batch_size x feature_size]
>>> result = mps_layer(data)
>>> print(result.shape)
torch.Size([20, 10])
property l_position#

Returns position of the output node (label).

property n_sites#

Returns number of nodes (inlcuding all input nodes and output node).

property boundary#

Returns boundary condition (“obc” or “pbc”).

property d_phys#

Returns physical dimension.

property d_bond#

Returns bond dimension.

property n_labels#

Returns number of labels in the output node. Same as phys_dim for input nodes.

param_bond(set_param=None)[source]#

Returns param_bond attribute or changes it if set_param is provided.

Parameters

set_param (bool, optional) – Boolean indicating whether edges have to be parameterized (True) or de-parameterized (False).

initialize(std=1e-09)[source]#

Initializes all the nodes.

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes and connects each of them to the physical edge of an input node.

contract(inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Contracts the whole MPS.

canonicalize(mode='svd', rank=None, cum_percentage=None, cutoff=None)[source]#

Turns MPS into canonical form via local SVD/QR decompositions.

Parameters

  • mode ({"svd", "svdr", "qr"}) – Indicates which decomposition should be used to split a node after contracting it. See more at svd_(), svdr_(), qr_(). If mode is “qr”, operation qr_() will be performed on nodes at the left of the output node, whilst operation rq_() will be used for nodes at the right.

  • rank (int, optional) – Number of singular values to keep.

  • cum_percentage (float, optional) –

    Proportion that should be satisfied between the sum of all singular values kept and the total sum of all singular values.

    \[\frac{\sum_{i \in \{kept\}}{s_i}}{\sum_{i \in \{all\}}{s_i}} \ge cum\_percentage\]

  • cutoff (float, optional) – Quantity that lower bounds singular values in order to be kept.

canonicalize_univocal()[source]#

Turns MPS into the univocal canonical form defined here.

class tensorkrowch.UMPSLayer(n_sites, d_phys, n_labels, d_bond, l_position=None, param_bond=False, num_batches=1, inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Class for Uniform (translationally invariant) Matrix Product States with an extra node that is dedicated to the output. It is the uniform version of MPSLayer, that is, all input nodes share the same tensor. Thus this class cannot have different physical or bond dimensions for each site, and boundary conditions are always periodic.

Parameters

  • n_sites (int) – Number of sites, including all the input nodes and the output node.

  • d_phys (int) – Physical dimension.

  • n_labels (int) – Label dimension for the output node. Plays the same role as d_phys for input nodes.

  • d_bond (int) – Bond dimension.

  • l_position (int, optional) – Position of the output node (label). Should be between 0 and n_sites - 1. If None, the output node will be located at the middle of the MPS.

  • param_bond (bool) – Boolean indicating whether bond edges should be ParamEdge.

  • num_batches (int) – Number of batch edges of input data nodes. Usually num_batches = 1 (where the batch edge is used for the data batched) but it could also be num_batches = 2 (one edge for data batched, other edge for image patches in convolutional layers).

  • inline_input (bool) – Boolean indicating whether input data nodes should be contracted inline (one contraction at a time) or in a single stacked contraction.

  • inline_mats (bool) – Boolean indicating whether the sequence of matrices (resultant after contracting the input data nodes) should be contracted inline or as a sequence of pairwise stacked contrations.

property l_position#

Returns position of the output node (label).

property n_sites#

Returns number of nodes (inlcuding all input nodes and output node).

property d_phys#

Returns physical dimension.

property d_bond#

Returns bond dimension.

property n_labels#

Returns number of labels in the output node. Same as phys_dim for input nodes.

param_bond(set_param=None)[source]#

Returns param_bond attribute or changes it if set_param is provided.

Parameters

set_param (bool, optional) – Boolean indicating whether edges have to be parameterized (True) or de-parameterized (False).

initialize(std=1e-09)[source]#

Initializes output and uniform nodes.

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes and connects each of them to the physical edge of an input node.

contract(inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Contracts the whole MPS.

class tensorkrowch.ConvMPSLayer(in_channels, out_channels, d_bond, kernel_size, stride=1, padding=0, dilation=1, l_position=None, boundary='obc', param_bond=False, inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Class for Matrix Product States with an extra node that is dedicated to the output, and where the input data is a batch of images. It is the convolutional version of MPSLayer.

Input data as well as initialization parameters are described in nn.Conv2d.

Parameters

  • in_channels (int) – Input channels. Same as d_phys in MPSLayer.

  • out_channels (int) – Output channels. Same as n_labels in MPSLayer.

  • d_bond (int, list[int] or tuple[int]) – Bond dimension(s). If given as a sequence, its length should be equal to \(kernel\_size_0 \cdot kernel\_size_1 + 1\). The i-th bond dimension is always the dimension of the right edge of the i-th node (including output node).

  • kernel_size (int, list[int] or tuple[int]) – Kernel size used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • stride (int) –

    Stride used in nn.Unfold.

  • padding (int) –

    Padding used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • dilation (int) –

    Dilation used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • l_position (int, optional) – Position of the output node (label). Should be between 0 and \(kernel\_size_0 \cdot kernel\_size_1\). If None, the output node will be located at the middle of the MPS.

  • boundary ({'obc', 'pbc'}) – String indicating whether periodic or open boundary conditions should be used.

  • param_bond (bool) – Boolean indicating whether bond edges should be ParamEdge.

  • num_batches (int) – Number of batch edges of input data nodes. Usually num_batches = 1 (where the batch edge is used for the data batched) but it could also be num_batches = 2 (one edge for data batched, other edge for image patches in convolutional layers).

  • inline_input (bool) – Boolean indicating whether input data nodes should be contracted inline (one contraction at a time) or in a single stacked contraction.

  • inline_mats (bool) – Boolean indicating whether the sequence of matrices (resultant after contracting the input data nodes) should be contracted inline or as a sequence of pairwise stacked contrations.

Examples

>>> conv_mps_layer = tk.ConvMPSLayer(in_channels=2,
...                                  out_channels=10,
...                                  d_bond=5,
...                                  kernel_size=2)
>>> data = torch.ones(20, 2, 2, 2) # batch_size x in_channels x height x width
>>> result = conv_mps_layer(data)
>>> print(result.shape)
torch.Size([20, 10, 1, 1])
property in_channels#

Returns in_channels. Same as d_phys in MPSLayer.

property kernel_size#

Returns kernel_size. Number of nodes is given by \(kernel\_size_0 \cdot kernel\_size_1 + 1\).

property stride#

Returns stride used in nn.Unfold.

property padding#

Returns padding used in nn.Unfold.

property dilation#

Returns dilation used in nn.Unfold.

forward(image, mode='flat', *args, **kwargs)[source]#

Overrides nn.Module’s forward to compute a convolution on the input image.

Parameters

  • image (torch.Tensor) –

    Input batch of images with shape

    \[batch\_size \times in\_channels \times height \times width\]

  • mode ({"flat", "snake"}) – Indicates the order in which MPS should take the pixels in the image. When "flat", the image is flattened putting one row of the image after the other. When "snake", its row is put in the opposite orientation as the previous row (like a snake running through the image).

class tensorkrowch.ConvUMPSLayer(in_channels, out_channels, d_bond, kernel_size, stride=1, padding=0, dilation=1, l_position=None, param_bond=False, inline_input=False, inline_mats=False)[source]#

Class for Uniform Matrix Product States with an extra node that is dedicated to the output, and where the input data is a batch of images. It is the convolutional version of UMPSLayer. This class cannot have different bond dimensions for each site and boundary conditions are always periodic.

Input data as well as initialization parameters are described in nn.Conv2d.

Parameters

  • in_channels (int) – Input channels. Same as d_phys in UMPSLayer.

  • out_channels (int) – Output channels. Same as n_labels in UMPSLayer.

  • d_bond (int) – Bond dimension.

  • kernel_size (int, list[int] or tuple[int]) –

    Kernel size used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • stride (int) –

    Stride used in nn.Unfold.

  • padding (int) –

    Padding used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • dilation (int) –

    Dilation used in nn.Unfold. If given as an int, the actual kernel size will be (kernel_size, kernel_size).

  • l_position (int, optional) – Position of the output node (label). Should be between 0 and \(kernel\_size_0 \cdot kernel\_size_1\). If None, the output node will be located at the middle of the MPS.

  • param_bond (bool) – Boolean indicating whether bond edges should be ParamEdge.

  • num_batches (int) – Number of batch edges of input data nodes. Usually num_batches = 1 (where the batch edge is used for the data batched) but it could also be num_batches = 2 (one edge for data batched, other edge for image patches in convolutional layers).

  • inline_input (bool) – Boolean indicating whether input data nodes should be contracted inline (one contraction at a time) or in a single stacked contraction.

  • inline_mats (bool) – Boolean indicating whether the sequence of matrices (resultant after contracting the input data nodes) should be contracted inline or as a sequence of pairwise stacked contrations.

property in_channels#

Returns in_channels. Same as d_phys in UMPSLayer.

property kernel_size#

Returns kernel_size. Number of nodes is given by \(kernel\_size_0 \cdot kernel\_size_1 + 1\).

property stride#

Returns stride used in nn.Unfold.

property padding#

Returns padding used in nn.Unfold.

property dilation#

Returns dilation used in nn.Unfold.

forward(image, mode='flat', *args, **kwargs)[source]#

Overrides nn.Module’s forward to compute a convolution on the input image.

Parameters

  • image (torch.Tensor) –

    Input batch of images with shape

    \[batch\_size \times in\_channels \times height \times width\]

  • mode ({"flat", "snake"}) – Indicates the order in which MPS should take the pixels in the image. When "flat", the image is flattened putting one row of the image after the other. When "snake", its row is put in the opposite orientation as the previous row (like a snake running through the image).

Tree#

class tensorkrowch.Tree(sites_per_layer, d_bond, param_bond=False, num_batches=1)[source]#

Create an Tree module.

Parameters

  • sites_per_layer (number of sites in each layer of the tree) –

  • d_bond (bond dimensions of nodes in each layer. In each layer, all) – nodes have the same shape, formed by various input edges and a single output edge. d_bond should be a sequence of sequences, one for each layer. Each sequence is formed by the bond dimensions of the input edges and the bond dimension of the output (last element in the sequence)

  • param_bond (boolean indicating whether bond edges should be parametric) –

  • num_batches (number of batch edges of input data) –

param_bond(set_param=None)[source]#

Return param_bond attribute or change it if set_param is provided.

Parameters

set_param (boolean indicating whether edges have to be parameterized) – (True) or de-parameterized (False)

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes with as many batch edges as num_batch_edges and one feature edge, and connects each of these feature edges to an edge from the list input_edges (following the provided order).

If all the data nodes have the same shape, a virtual node will contain all the tensors stacked in one, what will save some memory and time in computations.

This method can be overriden in subclasses so that it is specified in its implementation to which edges of the network the data nodes should be connected. In this case, there is no need to call set_data_nodes explicitly during training, since it will be done in the forward() call. Otherwise, it should be called before starting training.

Parameters

  • input_edges (list[int] or list[Edge or ParamEdge]) – List of edges (or indices of edges() if given as int) to which the data nodes’ feature edges will be connected.

  • num_batch_edges (int) – Number of batch edges in the data nodes.

PEPS#

class tensorkrowch.PEPS(n_rows, n_cols, d_phys, d_bond, boundary=['obc', 'obc'], param_bond=False, num_batches=1)[source]#

Create an PEPS module.

Parameters

  • n_rows (number of rows in the grid) –

  • n_cols (number of columns in the grid) –

  • d_phys (physical dimension) –

  • d_bond (bond dimension, it should only have 2 elements, the d_bond of) – horizontal edges and the d_bond of vertical edges

  • boundary (list of strings indicating whether we are using periodic or open) – boundary conditions in the horizontal and vertical boundaries

  • param_bond (boolean indicating whether bond edges should be parametric) –

  • num_batches (number of batch edges of input data) –

param_bond(set_param=None)[source]#

Return param_bond attribute or change it if set_param is provided.

Parameters

set_param (boolean indicating whether edges have to be parameterized) – (True) or de-parameterized (False)

set_data_nodes()[source]#

Creates data nodes with as many batch edges as num_batch_edges and one feature edge, and connects each of these feature edges to an edge from the list input_edges (following the provided order).

If all the data nodes have the same shape, a virtual node will contain all the tensors stacked in one, what will save some memory and time in computations.

This method can be overriden in subclasses so that it is specified in its implementation to which edges of the network the data nodes should be connected. In this case, there is no need to call set_data_nodes explicitly during training, since it will be done in the forward() call. Otherwise, it should be called before starting training.

Parameters

  • input_edges (list[int] or list[Edge or ParamEdge]) – List of edges (or indices of edges() if given as int) to which the data nodes’ feature edges will be connected.

  • num_batch_edges (int) – Number of batch edges in the data nodes.

contract(from_side='up', max_bond=32, inline=True)[source]#

Contracts the whole tensor network returning a single Node. This method is not implemented and should be overriden in subclasses of TensorNetwork.

  • num_batch_edges (int) – Number of batch edges in the data nodes.

contract(from_side='up', max_bond=32, inline=True)[source]#

Contracts the whole tensor network returning a single Node. This method is not implemented and should be overriden in subclasses of TensorNetwork.

class tensorkrowch.ConvPEPS(in_channels, d_bond, kernel_size, stride=1, padding=0, dilation=1, boundary=['obc', 'obc'], param_bond=False)[source]#
forward(image, *args, **kwargs)[source]#

Contract Tensor Network with input data with shape batch x n_features x feature.

Overrides the forward method of PyTorch nn.Module. Sets data nodes automatically whenever set_data_nodes is overriden, adds data tensor(s) to these nodes, and contracts the whole network according to contract(), returning a single torch.Tensor.

It can be called using the __call__ operator ().

Parameters

  • data (torch.Tensor or list[torch.Tensor], optional) –

    If all data nodes have the same shape, thus having its tensor stored in “stack_data_memory”, data should be a tensor of shape

    \[n_{features} \times batch\_size_{0} \times ... \times batch\_size_{n} \times feature\_size.\]

    Otherwise, it should be a list with \(n_{features}\) elements, each of them being a tensor with shape

    \[batch\_size_{0} \times ... \times batch\_size_{n} \times feature\_size.\]

    Also, it is not necessary that the network has data nodes, thus None is also valid.

  • args – Arguments that might be used in contract().

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments that might be used in contract().

class tensorkrowch.ConvUPEPS(in_channels, d_bond, kernel_size, stride=1, padding=0, dilation=1, param_bond=False)[source]#
forward(image, *args, **kwargs)[source]#

Contract Tensor Network with input data with shape batch x n_features x feature.

Overrides the forward method of PyTorch nn.Module. Sets data nodes automatically whenever set_data_nodes is overriden, adds data tensor(s) to these nodes, and contracts the whole network according to contract(), returning a single torch.Tensor.

It can be called using the __call__ operator ().

Parameters

  • data (torch.Tensor or list[torch.Tensor], optional) –

    If all data nodes have the same shape, thus having its tensor stored in “stack_data_memory”, data should be a tensor of shape

    \[n_{features} \times batch\_size_{0} \times ... \times batch\_size_{n} \times feature\_size.\]

    Otherwise, it should be a list with \(n_{features}\) elements, each of them being a tensor with shape

    \[batch\_size_{0} \times ... \times batch\_size_{n} \times feature\_size.\]

    Also, it is not necessary that the network has data nodes, thus None is also valid.

  • args – Arguments that might be used in contract().

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments that might be used in contract().
